Title: Inequality in 3D – measurement and implications for macroeconomic theory

This project aims to advance our understanding of the complex interactions between inequality and the macroeconomy. By measuring the economy at the household level across three dimensions – consumption, income, and wealth – we will provide a more nuanced understanding of the distribution of economic resources and its implications for macroeconomic theory. Our approach combines novel microdata with heterogeneous agent models, contrasting with traditional representative agent models, to quantify the micro heterogeneity that matters for macroeconomic theory. 

Through disciplined empirical efforts informed by recent modeling developments, we expect to inform the development of current and future macroeconomic models, providing novel insights for improvements in fiscal and monetary policy tools. Our research will also contribute to the ongoing debate on economic inequality, providing lessons for policymakers on how to address this pressing issue. By better understanding the mechanisms underlying inequality and its macroeconomic implications, we can ultimately inform more effective policy decisions that promote economic stability and prosperity for all. This project has the potential to make a significant impact on our understanding of the economy and our ability to address pressing social and economic challenges.
